metadata.title: Latin-to-English Translations: Cited Statistics
metadata.methodology: All figures sourced from official publisher/database websites or peer-reviewed scholarship
metadata.note: Each statistic includes source citation for verification

library_of_latin_texts.citation: Library of Latin Texts (LLT), Brepolis/Brepols Publishers, 2024. 'Users can access an extensive collection of Latin texts, comprising over 167 million words across 12,149 works and diplomatic charters.'

ustc.source: USTC Editions July 2025.accdb (direct database analysis) + ustc.ac.uk/about
ustc.citation: Direct count from USTC database export, July 2025 edition. 'The USTC currently contains bibliographical descriptions of more than 1.6 million editions.'

language_breakdown.source: Direct analysis of USTC Editions July 2025.accdb, field: language_1

latin_editions_detail.source: Direct analysis of USTC Editions July 2025.accdb

search_fields.source: Edinburgh Legal History Blog, 2014; USTC database schema

medieval_manuscripts.source: Buringh, Eltjo. Medieval Manuscript Production in the Latin West: Explorations with a Global Database. Leiden: Brill, 2011. (Global Economic History Series, vol. 6)
medieval_manuscripts.citation: Buringh (2011): 'In total, some eleven million books were copied in this medieval period [500-1500], of which some seven million were still extant in 1500.' Also: 'Drawing on a vast range of sources... Buringh estimates that there are approximately 2.9 million medieval manuscripts in the world today.'

phi_latin_texts.coverage: Essentially all Latin literary texts written before A.D. 200, plus some later antiquity
phi_latin_texts.citation: PHI Latin Texts: 'This website contains essentially all Latin literary texts written before A.D. 200, as well as some texts selected from later antiquity.'
phi_latin_texts.note: Exact word count not published by PHI; one third-party analysis found 6,321,361 words across 174 classical texts (see Latin Stack Exchange)

loeb_classical_library.citation: Wikipedia: 'The 429 out of 558 LCL volumes below (76%) are in the public domain... The series included basic translations of classical literature, growing to include at least 537 different works, some in multiple volumes.'
loeb_classical_library.note: Exact Latin/Greek breakdown not officially published; red=Latin, green=Greek covers

i_tatti_renaissance_library.source: Wikipedia, 'The I Tatti Renaissance Library'; Harvard University Press
i_tatti_renaissance_library.citation: Wikipedia: 'In March 2025, the series published its 100th volume... As of 2021, the series had sold more than 100,000 copies.'
i_tatti_renaissance_library.note: Many volumes contain first English translations of Renaissance Latin works

dumbarton_oaks_medieval_library.citation: Direct count from DOML volumes page, December 2024

fathers_of_the_church.citation: Internet Archive: 'The Fathers Of The Church, A New Translation, 147 Volumes'. CUA Press blog (June 2024) discusses volumes 147-148.

oxford_medieval_texts.note: Exact count varies by how counted; series ongoing

collected_works_of_erasmus.citation: UTP: Called 'one of the scholarly triumphs of our time'

philological_museum.citation: Sutton: 'An Analytic Bibliography of On-line Neo-Latin Texts' contains 79,760 items

perseus_digital_library.note: Major classical authors with translations; exact count not published

global_medieval_sourcebook.note: Multi-language including Latin; many first translations

ian_bruce_scientific.content: Newton Principia, Euler works, Gauss, Bernoulli, etc.

estimates_requiring_verification.loeb_latin_vs_greek_split: Not officially published; commonly cited as roughly 50/50
estimates_requiring_verification.total_works_translated: No comprehensive count exists; estimate 8,000-15,000 based on series totals
estimates_requiring_verification.ustc_latin_percentage: Commonly cited as 50-70% Latin; not officially broken down
estimates_requiring_verification.phi_word_count: 6.3M cited in one analysis; not officially published
